content.label: This game is driving me crazy I can't put it down like it's sometimes gets really scary and it's challenging totally worth the money
With some unique and fun game mechanics

I cannot begin to express my awe for this game. It's level of interaction is just unparalleled. I say this because not only can you fully explore the world, but you can also manipulate the map itself with the use of 'time towers', changing the world you walk through. Incredible. My boyfriend and I cannot put the game down. We like putting it on our Apple TV and playing it from the couch. This is an amazing game, and right after I finish this review I'm going to play it through again.

ever had a warm spot in your heart for interactive fiction or choose-the-adventure books? if so, you absolutely must play this beautiful masterpiece. the bad thing is it's so hard to stop playing!

Played for hours. Very well done. Improvements over the previous two. I've re downloaded the first two now just to play through with the same character , especially so that I'll have the spell components. I will say that it is infuriating when they get stolen. You also should be able to speed up the guy walking from place to place.
Really good game although I liked 2 better since there wasn't as much swindlestones!  I only got to play dice once but had the option to talk anout it a load of times.

title.label: my favorite series of games on mobile, period.

content.label: sorcery! 1 & 2 were addictive and enthralling, and 3 is no different! inkle is doing a fantastic job. i hope to see other gamebooks adapted to this format once sorcery! 4 is out!!

Reading fighting fantasy game books when I was a boy is one my happiest memories. Waiting for Sorcery!3 reminds me of those days waiting eagerly for each new novel to come out. Thank you, inkle, you folks have not only honored the original books, but have created a new way to discover these adventures for a new generation.

title.label: Ups the ante, but only just

content.label:
Having played Sorcery 1 and 2, I had to get 3.  However, two days later I am done with it and have no desire to play it again.  While it was not as frustrating as Sorcery 2 with mandatory replays to finish, it has similar issues with some hard to find quest areas.  

Pros:
-The changing environment with the beacons' light
-Nice continuity with the first two
-More interesting monsters to fight and a few new spells 
-Swindlestones is back!  But another game or some variant rules or handicaps would have been nice.

Cons:
-Some non-choice decision trees
-Too short (to be fair the main story is probably a little longer than Sorcery 2 without the backtracking)
-Relatively empty landscape so a lot of your quest is spent traveling, eating and sleeping (and stupid mud trying to slurp up your boots).  It's particularly evident when you're running around looking for the last serpent you missed somehow.
- The ending is...less than epic.  Sure it's not the final chapter, but there's no building to a climax here; just a to do list and a nebulous time limit.

So in summary Sorcery 3 is a solid, albeit short, game book.  It is a fitting continuation of the saga but if you had problems with previous installments this is more of the same.

title.label: Shut up and take my money

content.label: Love, love, love inkle games, and this is no exception.

The craft and care on display here is fantastic. The descriptions are atmospheric, changing with time of day and level of fatigue. The gameplay challenges have multiple solutions, so many different playstyles can get you to the end of the game successfully (though killing ALL seven serpents is a challenge, especially if you don't keep your eyes open for clues). Nearly every problem can be tackled in multiple ways, and unlike the gamebooks that inspired it, the game is pretty scrupulous about keeping players from innocently locking themselves out of victory. 

(That is to say, if you can't get a boat to cross that lake, your quest isn't unwinnable... but you might need to do a lot of swimming.)

Finally, there's a game mechanic I won't spoil that knocked my socks off, was probably a nightmare to code so smoothly, and gives nearly every location in the game depth, revisitability, and a sense of history.

I still prefer Sorcery! 2 for its fantastic setting, but it's amazing that this adaptation/rewrite of S3 made it even NEARLY as good.

Must buy.
Get it :)

I bought the Inkle bundle months ago on a hunch that it might be worthwhile. Best game purchasing decision I've ever made. I was instantly hooked onto the Sorcery series, and have been awaiting this game since the announcement. I love it! I feel like Sorcery 3 encourages you to use more spells than the other 2 games (at least the way I played them), and the time mechanic is very interesting. If you love games that draw you in, and don't mind a bit of reading, then I encourage you to get this!

One note is that on my iPad mini 2nd gen, the device gets quite warm while playing the game and drains the battery awfully quick compared to the first two in the series. It might be the new mechanics at work or just isn't fully optimized yet. I've had a couple of crashes, but the game auto saves after almost every event, so no worries there.

title.label: Great game, very tough on battery life

content.label:
I love the original books in Sorcery series, but Inkle has done better and added terrific touches that bring the story to life! Great additions include: an addictive swindle stones game, and puzzle elements from the beacon towers.

3 star rating because of this bug! The game seriously kills my battery life. A session of sorcery could leave my iPhone 5s uncomfortably hot to hold, and drains my battery in 2 hours.

I would be playing this at 100% and by half an hour or so, I'd be down to 75%, give or take. 

The game is as challenging as its predecessors, along with the new animate map and Beacon puzzles, it is a refreshing take on the entire series! Just be sure your packed to the brim with rations, you only have like four chances to get any food, not counting foraging and finding nourishing moss.
Oh man. I just love it. It's a huge game, well worth the cost. I can understand now why we had to wait so long... This is an outrageous amount of content! Thank you inkle!
Not what I expected.  I wasted my money on what the reviews indicated
Crashes every time! Waste of money!

- Huge world to explore and any new paths.
- one of the best 'choose your adventure' books and software. 
- I do wish the music/sound volume could be turned off in the app.

I just beat the most complicated book in the series with all 7 serpents dead in just 18 days! I hope others will post their times bellow so that the devs can see the records too! As always amazing work Inkle I have all of your games and have enjoyed them all and am looking forward to book #4.

title.label: Inkle raises the bar for the third time with Sorcery 3

content.label:
It's a lot more than expected with fresh ideas brought to a new gaming genre being developed at Inkle.

They've entirely reworked what a digital game book can be.  Breathtaking, non linear interactivity and freedom to move back and forth across the land.

Perhaps they've gone a little too far as I never disliked the essential linear and canned nature of game books.  They've also taken more extensive liberties with the story line then we've seen before.

Still I'm impressed with this bold and ground breaking installment.  It's now obvious why Inkle required more time to bring this installment to us.  I would just suggest a more perfect balance of game / story would dial it back to where you aren't frequently faced with wondering where to go or what to do next or feeling like you're running against a clock.

Please note that due to the much more sophisticated 3D map performance is unsatisfactory on older devices such as my iPhone 4.  I'm playing on my LG Nexus 5 where it runs flawlessly until I get my iPad repaired.

Good:
Ever more sophisticated gaming mechanics (spell effect timers, daily status updates, et al)
3D map updates
Increasing complexity of spell system (new spells & spell countering)

Less Good:
A bit too open ended?
Too many liberties with original lore?
Poor graphics performance 

Highly recommended!

There's nothing else like the Sorcery! series. In essence, they're a choose-your-own-adventure fantasy adventure. But playing them is far more exciting than that description suggests. No one does rich, novelistic text-driven games the way Inkle does, and Sorcery! is their crown jewel. Their worlds are so rich that you'll want to play through the series at least twice. 

Within the series so far, I would rank Sorcery! 2 as the best and Sorcery! 3 as a close second, but all three are 5-star games in my book. Nothing you can play on a touchscreen is as rewarding.

title.label: Keeps crashing on iPad Mini very.1

content.label: I am enjoying the continued story and enhancements but the games continues to crash on my iPad Mini very. 1.  I hope the Inkle will notice and fix soon. I am not losing my progress but it is annoying AL, the same.

title.label: Fun Game but lots of crashes

content.label: I have an iPad mini and the game is crashing alot. if there were no crashes this would be a 5 star review for sure. Very cool game, now i want to buy and play 1 & 2 as well.

title.label: One of the best mobile has to offer

content.label: What can I say? Sorcery! Is possibly one of the best titles in mobile gaming, and if you haven't tried the series yet and have been looking for an actual game rather than a skinner box, this is the one you should start with.

This app has a fascinating storyline and an adventure I just couldn't put down. I literally played this app and finished it in a course of 3 days. It has great graphics and the ability to choose what your character will do is exciting. Also, it's pretty fun seeing what your spirit turns into based on your choices. Definitely worth the money, in my opinion inkle deserves more, but it's the best app I've seen in a long while. Can't wait until the 4th one!!!!
Was really enthusiastic about it, but then got bored pretty soon after playing the game.
The first two games in the series were amazing, and this one is even better! Definitely more than worth the five dollars.

I am playing on an iPad Mini and am experiencing frequent game crashes.

With the crashes gone this would get 5 stars.

title.label: The first truly open world text rpg.

content.label:
It might be somewhat of a defamation to even call this game text based: The map and environment art that meticulously illustrate most every detail of the game's world certainly belie such a description. Yet this game represents the culmination, in many senses, of the text based game. The encounters, the puzzles, even the combat are all text based, and the game as a whole is adapted from (though it has greatly expanded upon) a pen and paper gamebook from 1984. All of these have been excellently and seamlessly translated to the electronic medium, and players of the first two Sorcery games will be able to attest to the magnificent competency that Inkle has displayed in pure adaptation. But the revolution that this game represents would have been too much for that storied medium, for want of player patience in recording all the variables that are now electronically tracked if not nothing else. The game takes the player across four distinct yet interconnected environments (each fleshed out and interesting individually) and gives the player free reign to explore them. It may not be immediately apparent how incredible a feat of game design that is in itself. Text based games have long endeavored to provide the illusion of freedom, with various degrees of success. This is not unique to text based games, but it has been more necessary for them on account of their basic nature. Text based games create a world through narrative. When movement or phenomena are conveyed by the narrative they are described rather than displayed; and so repetition would be far more monotonous and far less tolerated than it would be for a more visual medium. Think of Assassins Creed 4 and its ship taking animation: every time a ship is taken the same animation takes place (albeit with slightly different character models). This kind of repetition is tolerated in a visual medium because the spectacle is absorbed passively. But in a text based medium, where the reader has to work to absorb the information, this sort of repetition would be regarded as insulting rather than merely discourteous, and the user experience would suffer. In order to avoid this, the text based game has traditionally insured that the player only experiences any given encounter once per playthrough, by funneling him/her in one direction, usually with some sort of story based justification (such as a pressing journey, or a race around the world.) This same approach was used in Mass Effect 3, with the majority of gameplay taking place in environments that are only accessible once per playthrough. After all, if you wanted to make a realistic rapidly collapsing frontline freely accessible, youd have to design multiple environments to reflect the changes that would presumably be taking place throughout the game: Youd need a pre-invasion Thessia, a first contact Thessia, a deteriorated Thessia, and a devastated Thessia. Every character would have to have dialogue reflecting each unique situation; every building would need different models for various states of repair. That task, compounded across multiple environments, would have multiplied the development costs, and the workload. The financial cost required for the extra HD art textures and animations would have likely rendered the game unprofitable. The effort that would be required to write and record for so many theoretical situations (that the player would likely never even see) would be irrational. But text is cheap, and Inkle is insane. They did exactly that. Every environment in the game can be explored at any time. You can walk back to the starting area a stones throw away from the ending. Hell, you are encouraged to: a fast travel hub lies right next to the end (Thats right, fast travel in a text game-and it needs it too!) Rather than break or buckle from the enormity of the task, Inkle has embraced it, by giving the player the power to transform any (any) part of the game world into an entirely different terrain (think desert into farmland, Steppe into Swamp). With these changes the character interactions change, the treasures to be found change, the random encounters change (this game doesnt overdo random encounters). And whats even more, these alternate forms feed into each other. A man killed on one version of an environment may be a rotting corpse on the other. A Woman beat in dice in one version may leave a message for you based on that in the other. (People who have played the previous games in the Sorcery saga will have even more variables depending on what choices they made in those games).There are many other positive remarks I could make about this game, about the minigames never seeming tacked on, or the lack of micro-transactions, or the superiority of the save transfer system. But you should really experience those things for yourself. This game is $5.00. Thats because its only a text based game on the App store. But because its text based it does things that no other game has ever attempted. Because its text based, extra environments were a matter of work and ingenuity rather than money. Because its text based, this game is the best game on the App store.
PS. Since they dont fit into the context of the review, Ill put my complaints here. Poor optimization for iPad mini (over world text is sometimes hard to read, due to what I guess is bad resolution scaling) occasional lag, occasional crashes. Other than the poor screen resolution scaling, I regard all of these problems as inevitable and blame them on my old hardware (original 2012 model) rather than the game.

I played the first the sorcery games and fell in love with the series. After playing a couple hours of this new one I can tell the amount of effort put into improvements. The game might seem expensive for $5 but it's worth it. For the price of a cheeseburger you can get one of the best apps on the App Store and hours of entertainment.
Really good game, recommend it if you liked the other sorcery! Games

I loved gamebooks as a kid; I spent a lot of time reading (and playing) quite a few of them. If I had known then what the pinnacle of the art form would eventually look likethis brilliant electronic version of the Sorcery! seriesI'm not sure my childhood self would have been able to handle the sheer awesomeness of it at the time. 

(Of course, the whole concept of smartphones probably would've blown my mind first. But these amazing books-turned-apps would be a VERY close second.)

title.label: Literally better than the lord of the rings

content.label: That's right.
I've been waiting for this game since Sorcery! 2 arrived. This one is surely the best. With time travel and open world exploration, I highly suggest adding this to your collection!

I have not played the game yet, but I'm willing to bet the $5 I've spent on this game that it will be absolutely fantastic while writing this review and waiting for it to download. The first and second instalments of the series were exemplary on its own right, and I'm certain that the third instalment will set the bar for digital gamebooks above and beyond 80 days and sorcery 1 and sorcery 2.
